field_edited_text.value:
Benefits Many financial as well as aesthetic benefits will accrue
to the City to compensate for the out-of-pocket costs, the loss
in taxables, and the maintenance expenses of the Park.

190 acres in potential development areas along the edges of
the Valley are shown. 138 of these are now vacant; the
remainder are underdeveloped or badly developed. Once the
Park Plan is adopted, they will have an investment potential
of over $85,000,000. This would return to the City in excess
of $2 million a year in taxes. While some of this might be
developed anyway, no estimate has been made of the
undoubted increase in value of other property adjacent to the
Valley.

In addition, the 58-acre tract over and adjacent to Penn Sta-
tion alone has a potential of $100,000,000 in investment. This
is sound municipal arithmetic.

COST ANALYSIS

Implementation and Financing The Plan can be achieved through
a step-by-step process of implementation. That process is
itemized under Recommendations.

Various techniques and sources of funds are available. Out-
right acquisition of property is indicated for most of the Val-
ley within the City. For some portions in the City, the pur-
chasing of development rights, made possible by recent State
legislation, may be appropriate. Such uses as the Woodberry
Methodist Church, the Mt. Washington Methodist Church, the
Meadowbrook Club, and the Mt. Washington Lacrosse Club
can be ensured by this method, or by purchase and lease-back.
Many of the houses can be acquired in the same manner. Most
of the land for the Park in Baltimore County can be protected
as open park space by acquisition of scenic easements or
development rights.

Major financing of the Valley Park in the City must be by a
local bond issue. However, 50-50 Federal funds may be avail-
able for portions of the Jones Falls Valley Road. Federal
money ig already available under the 90-10 ratio for landscap-
ing the expressway.

In addition to these Federal funds, there is likely to be a new
and direct aid for the Valley Plan. The Williams Bill (S. 858,
87th Congress sponsored by Senator Harrison A. Williams, Jr.
(D., N.J.)) was introduced in the Senate on February 9, 1961.
It calls for the authorization of grants up to 25-35% of acqui-
sition costs to help finance the preservation of open-space land
“which is of regional or area-wide importance . . .” President
Kennedy called for passage of this bill in his message to Con-
gress. When the bill is enacted into law, Baltimore can be
ready with one of the first qualifying plans. Recently Senator
Williams said to a meeting of the Maryland Governor’s Con-
ference on Recreation and Parks: “We must start making our
parks serve the larger effort of improving the whole quality
of urban and metropolitan living.” Hear, Hear!
